abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Agricultural
            Rehabilitation Project in Chad project are to: 1) improve
            coordination through the development of key rural
            institutions and the emergency rehabilitation of productive
            facilities in the rural sector; and 2) for the longer term,
            it aimed to enhance the governments ability to guide
            agricultural planning and development, by implementing pilot
            actions to establish optimum approaches in rural development
            and by carrying out key sub-sector studies. The project
            implementation period was consistent with the original
            five-year execution plan, but with a six-month delay in
            credit effectiveness and a three-month extension in credit
            closing. However, due to a slower than expected disbursement
            schedule, total project costs represented about 80 percent
            of original estimates, leaving a canceled balance. Key
            factors responsible for this slow disbursement were: (1)
            delays in procurement decisions due to Government heavy and
            inefficient procedures for approving annual project
            activities and budgets; and (b) inadequate provision of
            local counterpart fund due to misinterpretation by
            Government of the required level of local counterpart fund,
            lead to a suspension of disbursements under the special
            account for one year.

docna.cdata!:
Chad - Agricultural Rehabilitation Project :
            Credit 1775 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Chad - Agricultural
            Rehabilitation Project : Credit 1775 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
This agricultural rehabilitation project
            for Chad has two distinct objectives for rehabilitating the
            agricultural sector and accelerating development in the wake
            of a devastating civil war (1979-82) and a debilitating
            drought (1984). First, it would improve coordination through
            the development of key rural institutions and the emergency
            rehabilitation of productive facilities in the rural sector.
            Improved coordination would be achieved through
            institutional development of such key services as the
            Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development. This would be
            accomplished by providing resident experts, consulting
            services, vehicles and equipment. The emergency
            rehabilitation of productive facilities would involve
            re-establishing and developing immediately productive
            facilities in the rural sector, both for public sector
            enterprises and for key rural development services. Second,
            for the long term, this project would enhance the
            Government's ability to guide agricultural planning and
            development by implementing pilot actions to establish
            optimum approaches in rural development and by carrying out
            key sub-sector studies. Pilot actions to be initiated, for
            example, would include testing new technologies for
            expanding food crop production and water resource maintenance.
